did.abstract: The Henry Street Settlement Music School records contain correspondence, financial records, reports, statistics and scrapbooks. Also includes card files with student and faculty information.

accessrestrict.head: Use of Materials
accessrestrict.p: Open for use in Social Welfare History Archives reading room.

userestrict.head: Copyright
userestrict.p: Please contact the Archivist for copyright information.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The Henry Street Settlement Music School records were received as a gift from the school in 1970 and 1975.

otherfindaid.head: Other Finding Aid
otherfindaid.p: Unpublished inventory available. Please contact Archives for more information.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: In addition to the above-described records of the Music School, the Social Welfare History Archives holds the records of Henry Street Settlement, the parent institution. These records contain scattered references to activities of the Music School as well as the Playhouse, whose dramatic productions often involved the Music School.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Music School of Henry Street Settlement was formed in 1927, although the Settlement had offered musical activities for residents of New York City's Lower East Side for many years. The new school, which opened to students in the fall of 1928, offered classes in instrumental and vocal music, dancing, and instrument construction and repair.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Henry Street Music School records demonstrate the school's determination to provide both excellence in individual instruction (as evidenced in the number of its students who went on to professional careers) and diverse musical activities that would appeal to all sectors of the community. Among the special events and projects documented in the records are the school's 1937 world premiere performance of Aaron Copland's opera, The Second Hurricane (Copland was a member of the school's advisory committee as were George Gershwin and Jascha Heifetz), and a 1960s project to allow young men released from the Riker's Island Prison for young offenders to continue the instrumental lessons they had begun while incarcerated.

The bulk of the records comprises scrapbooks of programs, photographs, and clippings from recitals, productions, and other performances and card files containing basic information on individual students and faculty members. Also included in the records are annual reports, committee minutes, correspondence, financial records, statistical reports on students, and loose programs and photographs. The individuals represented most prominently in the records are three of the school's directors: Hedi Katz (1927-1935); Grace Spofford (1935-1954); and Robert Egan (1954-1969).

controlaccess.head: Index Terms
controlaccess.p: This Henry Street Music School records are indexed under the following headings in the catalog of the University of Minnesota Libraries. Researchers desiring materials about related topics, persons or places should search the catalog using these headings.

scopecontent.p: Series 1 consists of three record storage boxes of administrative records of the Music School. Materials in series 1 include correspondence financial records, reports and statistics.

scopecontent.p: Series 2 contains 22 record storage boxes of student registration cards. The student cards are organized into several sets according to date span. Within each set, cards are usually filed alphabetically. There are also 4 boxes containing faculty record cards; index cards listing music books, scores, and texts; business cards for music companies, tuners and other service providers; and cards on supporters of the school. There are about 35,000 of these types of cards, combined, spanning 1932 to1969.

Faculty cards may include name, teaching position, date(s) of employment, and reason for leaving. Student cards may include name, date, address, occupation, birth date, birth place, parents' name(s), parents' birth place, parents' occupations, nationality, religion, date of previous study, current subject studied, name of teacher, and fee schedule.

did.unittitle: Cards of music books and scores arranged by instrument and composer

scopecontent.p: Series 3 is housed in 2 record center boxes, 3 oversize storage boxes and one legal length document box. Materials in Series 3 include newspaper clippings, photographs, concert programs, and information on benefits on behalf of the school.
